page.title: 10KNILL'S MONUMENT
page.content: { Knill's monument}a triangular, hollow pyramid on a square base.Built by John Knill, collector of customs at St Ives from 1762-82 and Mayor in 1767.In 1782 the monument was built as a mausoleum but was never consecrated and so was never used.{The Knill ceremony, }first carried out in 1801, takes place every 5 years on St. James Day, 25th July.10 little girls dressed in white, natives of the borough and daughters of seamen, fishermen or tinners not exceeding 10 years of age, accompanied by 2 elderly widows and led by a fiddler, go in procession from the Guildhall to the Malakoff. They are then taken by coach to Trelyon and complete the rest of the journey on foot.Here the group dance around the monument to the tune of the {Cornish Furry Dance.}
